THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES
AND SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW

J. D. MAVEETY

PRINCE ALBERT N.W.T.

This paper may be issued by anyone who desires.

This is a weekly newspaper, and will continue every week until further notice.

FRIDAY, SEPT. 3, 1886.

FICTION.

As most people have a taste for fiction in these degenerate days, we will, with your permission, gentle readers, give a brief chapter from a recent speech of the Hon. Mr. Mercer on the election of the House of Commons. We are aware that Mr. Mercer is a writer of fiction, but he can utter fiction with an ease and elegance only equaled, if fanged, by Mr. Mercer, and if he has the luck to see his prose, he will be forced to broken form he will hang quite an extensive work of fiction to hang his name down to posterity. But while Mr. Mercer excels in fiction, he excels in truth, which is the most necessary to disturb his peculiar turn of mind-in the pathetic, and we have no doubt many hot tears must have trickled down the cheeks of the French habitants whom he has both in his letters addressed to the churches and Chambly during the last few weeks. Yes, see that he excels in fiction, and it is because of our fear that strong minds may grow weak and forget who they are as we are suddenly plunged into a dark denseness that we have taken this somewhat tedious way of bringing this wonderful full part of fiction to your notice.

The evening service in the chapter is Bateher, and the author or whatever else you may call them our neighbours the Mets, and a Cockney, and is intended to illus- trate how the religion was brought about.

A young Cockney brought from Eng., land came along, with two or three hairs of hair and a child or two to the un- tame Metes. "Nice people," said Mr. Cockney, "but you are my property, and you must be good enough to get out."

"Hello, who are you?" says the Matso.

"I am an Irishman and a person from London, the son of a lord, or a noble- man of the House of Commons, or a big boy of some sort, and my father has purchased this land from the Canadian Govern-

ment."

"My boy, you come at me," replies the half-breed. "This is my farm, my children were raised here and I was raised here myself, and I intend to re-

main here."

"But I told you you must go out."

"I'm there a man in this meeting who won't get sick of doing that? Put up arms, it will do the trick."

And whilst he speaks, the stranger comes to take it away from him by means of a sword and pistol the latter, nor can be expected upon the Canadian soil, and not to feel his heart being broken in two pieces."

Here a loud cheer. "No wonder if they would fly to arise, for if there be anything in this world calculated to make a man put up to fighting pitch, it is the appearance of a Cockney with a sword and pistol in his hand."

But the Cockney, like Macdonald's New Zealanders, has yet to learn that Batoche, or any other man or set of men, in the character described by Mr. Mercer, those of you, however, who are familiar with this district, are acquainted with the Lakes connected with it, will doubtless be able to ap-

preciate Mr. Mercer's excellences or wonders. If you did not go to the Lakes' post, he will show himself to be utterly lacking the prime characteristic of prac-

tically—for whom—there seems to be no imagination himself in another country upon which he may be at home as one other. He perhaps imagined himself at Connell, and that was not addressed the peoples of Kerry.

What a pity that falsehood can always be made to serve the ends of the demagogue among an intelligent people.

THE HARVEST

From the reports we have received, we are convinced that Prince Albert's crop has suffered less from the drought during the past season than any other portion of the Northwest. The yield of crops, owing to the drought, has not been as high amongst ourselves as that which, but the quality of the crops, particularly owing to the absence of frost, will compare favourably with that of any other part of the terri-

tory. So much so, that some people believe it has been quite some time since Prince Albert has had such a good harvest. But suppose we must look for the reason of the small area of wheat being sown in the fact that many of the former ones were of the common kind. If it had been supplied them by the Government instead of as good quality as it should be. But whatever doubts crops are not as good as they should have been. Of our farmers more care was taken than others, gave the seed the benefit of the doubt, and the conse-

quence is that they are able pay back their loan and sell a good surplus of wheat at a reasonable price. We wish the success continues, the future of the colony must therefore, not be able to repay the amount called for without selling their surplus. In any case there will be a scarcity of seed of good quality next season.

With regard to the barley and oats we cannot give as favourable a re-

port. The seed barley while it may have been good, does not seem to have been marketed in sufficient quantity, and all we can say now the seed should be this. For this fact, which was caused by the drought, the effect rather barely what it would have been. But with barley, as with the

whats, though not so generally, some of the farmers were tolerably suc-

cessful. The same remarks would seem to apply to oats. The yield and the quality of the oats and barley, as a whole, therefore, is not nearly as satisfactory as that of wheat, and we are not too surprised if many of the farmers would find themselves unable this year to repay the seed advanced by the government.

As to the yield of potatoes, we can safely say that there is no likelihood of a shortage.

FARMING.

It will not, we trust, be considered out of place on our part if we make this suggestion regarding farming in general. To become a successful farmer a same knowledge of details, the same perseverance, is required as in any other business. Show us a successful farmer and we shall show you a patient, painstaking man. We do not say that he can control the climate. He has to take his chances with regard to that; but, he prepares to re-

ceive the gift in such a way as to make him, barring the natural draw-

backs, the greatest possible yield. He does not allow weeds to choke out his grain, absorb the moisture which should go towards nourishing it, and eat it as they are growing, burying them to draw out the soil and the grain to thrust through on the field for days after he cuts it. He wastes nothing, saves everything. We heard a farmer in this district who had six acres of Tynan's oats in entire de-

prived, his wall, and the common consensus was that notwithstanding the drought he had a good crop off the land on which he utilized it. This shows that the location makes all the difference, as also the chance you have of a good turn for your labour. We notice that some farmers do not take proper care of their farming imple-

ments, but leave them unshoed, unpolished and neglected. The conse-

quence is that in a short time they are cracked and rusted, and look as if they had come out of the Ark. This is to be regretted, as farming impli-

ments run very low. Our advice to the farmers is whatever they use to maintain let it be so done as to assure you the greatest possible reward for your labour.

EDITORIAL NOTES.

The North-West Council meets on the 3d of October.

The Chicago Anarchists have been arrested.

The promoters of the Regina and Long Lake Railway expect to complete the line to Prince Albert by next fall.

The Manitoba Legislative Council, the leading Liberal papers of Canada, Montreal, and other Liberal papers of the province, declare in support of the Rider proposition.

Sir John saw Victoria is only the ter-

minal of the C.P.R., the Canadian Pacific Railway, which covers the distance between that point and Vancouver. The mail cars of the railway will be longer than those of any other railway. What a splendid achievement!

The U.S. Congress is fast becoming a reflection of Prince Albert College has brought in a bill which provides for abating American ports against all the privileges enjoyed by Canadian non-

commercial vessels. Yet he says the S.S. has no more use for a treaty with Can-

ada than he has for the French Navy, as he would use it in war, whereas it is arranged both by treaty. The genera-

lized American commercial interests are pressing for a wider application of the terms on which Canadian ports on the territory of the U.S., but a denial of like privileges to Canadian American ports or of some sort and to valid purchasers

Arrangements are being made by the publishers of THE MANITOBA SUN for the publication of a Weekly Edition at an early date. The size of the paper will be Eight Pages of Seven Columns each—50 Columns all—and the price will be placed at the very low figure of $1.50 PER ANNUM.

THE WEEKLY EDITION will contain The News of the Week, Selected Miscellaneous, An Interesting Serial and Special Departments of Peculiar Interest to the Home Circle. No effort will be wanting to make our Weekly a welcome visitor every where.

Persons intending to subscribe are requested to send their names, with the price of subscription to the office of THE MANITOBA SUN, 2d Market St. E., Winnipeg, Man.

J. SINCLAIR & CO. Canada—North West Territories.

SHIPMENTS SALE OF LANDS.

By order of the Property of the Land of Prince of Wales, the land near the Saskatchewan River, on the site of the new town, will be sold for the sum of a quarter of a million dollars on the 13th March, if the sale takes place. The land is situated between the river and the town site, and comprises about 210 acres, according to a plan of survey of the Surveyor General. The land is situated near the townsite of Prince Albert, and is now occupied by the Government Station. The contract will be made with Mr. S. M. Smith, of the Surveyor General's Office, who will make arrangements for the sale of the land. The land will be divided into lots, and each lot will be sold for a certain sum. The land is located on the banks of the Saskatchewan River, and is suitable for settlement and cultivation. The land is situated in the town of Prince Albert, and is located on the site of the new town. The land is suitable for settlement and cultivation. The land is located on the banks of the Saskatchewan River, and is situated in the town of Prince Albert.

SHIPMENTS SALE OF LANDS.

By order of the Lieutenant-Governor of the Province of Manitoba, the land near the mouth of the Red River, between the town sites of Prince Albert and Beauport, will be sold for the sum of one hundred thousand dollars on the 13th March, if the sale takes place. The land is situated between the river and the town, and comprises about 400 acres. The land will be divided into lots, and each lot will be sold for a certain sum. The land is suitable for settlement and cultivation. The land is located near the townsite of Prince Albert, and is situated on the site of the new town.

FACTS FOR THE PEOPLE.

FROM THE CANADIAN HANDBOOK.

The value of Canadian goods exported in 1876 was $29,357,548; being $26,078,646 worth of goods the products of other countries. Of this amount Animals and their products yielded $20,237,704; furs, $3,088,000; minerals, $1,284,293; manufactures, $3,181,501; timber, $4,029,727; wheat, $7,806,000; miscellaneous, $557,374; total, $84,265,164. The value of cheese exported was $29,265,500. Canadian goods at the head of the list were the following:

The Canadian cattle export trade has increased from 25,337 heifers in 1877, to 143,003 in 1885; sheep, 141,187 to 335,043.

Total value of goods imported in 1885, $110,941,480. This was worth doing raw material for manufacturing purposes.

The paid up capital invested in banking on the 30th September last was $60,426,500; the value of government debt, last year, was $17,836,378.

The capital invested in manufacturing has increased from $77,094,000 in 1871, to $160,300,025 in 1881; hands employed, from 187,942 to 254,836; amount of yearly wages paid, from $1,199,092 to $1,992,092; value of raw material from $1,124,067 to $1,979,100; total value of articles manufactured in 1871, $221,617,778; in 1881, $351,675,056.

The accumulations of savings in Canada have increased from $6,000,000 in 1871, to $16,000,000 in 1881. The total amount of deposits in the Government Savings and other chartered banks was $36,108,981.

The wealth of Canada is estimated at $60,000,000,000, and the income $21,000,000,000. The average rate of interest is 4.27 per cent. The percentage of income or capital in Canada is 18.1; in the U.S., 14.3; Europe, 18.8; England, India, &c., 16.6; Australia, 22.5; one-tenth of the Crown lands of Canada as 36 an annual would more than suffice to pay the public debt.

At the end of last year Canada had 660 newspapers, 71 daily, 10 tri-weekly, 21 weekly, 463 semi-weekly, 13 monthly, and 73 bi-monthly. The percentage of income or capital in Canada is 18.1; in the U.S., 14.3; Europe, 18.8; England, India, &c., 16.6; Australia, 22.5; one-tenth of the Crown lands of Canada as 36 an annual would more than suffice to pay the public debt.

The number of pupils throughout the Dominion, in 1885, in public, high schools, 13,000; in Universities, 1,000; in private schools, 360; average attendance, 550,400; total expenditure, $1,000,000; in normal schools, $500,000; in technical schools, $250,000; furniture, $25,000,000; and 18,000 teachers were employed in the public schools.

Number of students of whom 18,000, 250,000,000; total expenditure, 2,000,000.

In 1885, 235 tons of fresh meat, 10 tons pork and beef, 115 tons preserved meats, 3,629 tons bacon and ham, 28 tons lard, 35,560 hogs' heads, 3,200 tons butter, 1,142,422 tons eggs, 1,142,422 tons eggs (sold in Canada), 11,542,422 tons eggs (sold in the U.S.), 988,825 tons flour, 621,692 hides, horns, &c., 1,758,590 poultry were exported by Canada.

The total mileage of railways in Canada is 12,275; total amount of capital all kinds held by the Government, $1,000,000; the amount of capital held by the people is up to the end of 1885, was $820,756,704. The earnings of the railways for the year ending June 30th, 1885, was $2,227,499; expenses, $2,013,012.

The total cost of the canal system (72 miles) of Canada up to 30th June, 1885, was $24,000.

Of the sea-going craft which, in 1885, entered and cleared, 5,190, with a tonnage of 750,000 tons.

The sea-going vessels entered and cleared at Canadian ports in 1885 amounted to 21,644, with a tonnage of 7,644,012, and carried 294,470 tons. These vessels brought cargoes to Canada from 47,306 tons of telegraph wire in Canada, and 2,400 stations.

Two ships of war visited Canada on 30th June, 1885; one was 7,000 tons.

The lighthouse system of Canada contains 300 sea coast lights, 229 land lights, 100 river lights, with fixed lights and 17 lights. The number of light stations with fixed lights is 467, with revolving lights 10.

Value of lumber exported in U.S., $9,353,736; to Canada, $57,557,581.

G. W. Folster and Norman McKay, of the firm of McKay & Folster, at Kinloch River, near the latter town Asia basin, arrived in town this week and will leave for Scotland, having retired from the service.

MOORE & MACDOWALL
COMMUNICATIONS.

SEED GRAIN.

To the Editor of The Times.

Sir,—It will be generally acknowledged that owing to the severe drought of the past season, grain, as a rule, will not average more than half its usual value in the market at that. The quantity now on hand, as a rule, small, and the return, also, is the same, though the former is more abundant which makes it suitable for seed next season.

Now, in regard to the terms. The Government charges us one hundred per cent., for the seed, whereas they tell me that, if the public accounts against the Government bear no interest, why the Government does not charge the public one hundred per cent., and that not in an ordinary way of business, but for the sake of the people, who are treated unfairly. As far as I know, in times of distress in other British colonies, where public works have been started, the other side was treated to assist the people, so such terms were enacted. And mark you, the farmers do not urge the Government to give each pack of grain to each pack of seed, but each pack of grain took hand to give the farmers their harvest. Could it be better bargain than the Government has offered? In fact—and I speak as one of them—the farmers would never have accepted such terms had they been in a position to refuse.

The freighting of the grain was a deal done by many, and a great number of farmers were thrown into debt by the demanding of two bushels in return for one grain must necessarily fail, such a demand being unreasonable.

When it was first suggested that the Government would supply seed for all at cost price, the farmers exclaimed: "How generous and thoughtful of Sir John!" But they did not know at the time how the security he was creating.

Let us hope that they will yet come down a great deal on their original terms, and allow the farmers a free hand to accept bushel for bushel, and at least pay many—a myself among others—who will be obliged to sell at a loss, and will not much more than see their farms ruined.

J. B.

Stoney Creek, August 21st, 1886.

[We do not suppose for one moment, that the Government, like Shylock, will exact the pound of flesh; at least, judging by its conduct, we may safely presume that it will, think, be grateful for the opportunity of doing so; those who cannot carry the wheat to market, or the government without distressing themselves will, we have no doubt, get an extension of time, and a little patience will overcome the heribitary, when we take into account the fact that the seed which is demanded by the farmers is worth by costs of the barley 6 cents, and oats 5 cents, and the further fact that two bushels of any other of our seed grain may not bring the price of one bushel, and the farmers do not think it reasonable. In any case the farmers must be asked to contribute towards the costs of the grain, two bushels for one. As to the writer's reflection on the generosity of Sir John, we agree with many patriots of Sir John, but not the least, in very bad taste; but we are in hopes that the government will both serve its purpose and show its own gratitude. From recent information, we are led to believe that his estimate of the yield of the wheat crop is correct, and is far below the mark, though he may be stating his own case correctly. As for the timber, we are sure that it is a free gift, we hardly think it will, and we thank further that no reasonable man would expect it.]

For the benefit of those who may not have the notice-board in the telegraph office we may state that telegrams must be sent through the telegraph offices for public business between the hours of 9 a.m. and 5 p.m., and from 7 p.m. to 9 p.m., in addition to the above hours, if a customer wishes to send a telegram outside the hours of 8 o'clock a.m. and 5 p.m., and between the hours of 8 o'clock p.m. and 9 p.m., he can do so by making arrangements with the telegraph office, and by paying in addition to the regular rate, the sum of five cents for each additional word, and the sending system, if the message has to be repeated at any station twenty-five cents additional per hour until the operator or station thereof obtains the operator beyond their regular office hours.

TELEGRAPHIC.

THE VERY LATEST NEWS BY WIRE.

(By Special Telegraph.)

Winnipeg, Sept. 3rd.—Captain Fritschler arrived at Winnipeg today, en route to discover the North Pole.

Pangnirtung, Sept. 3rd.—News of Captain Fritschler's discovery of the North Pole, has just arrived.

There have been important changes made in the cabinet of Manitoba province. The number of cabinet ministers has been increased from five to six by the creation of a portfolio of Ready Money. The new minister has been taken by the Hon. John Morneau, who gave up the Provincial Treasurer to the position. The new Provincial Agricultural Secretary has been appointed, whose admission to the cabinet has long been anticipated. Mr. William Hamilton Gibson, the latter becoming Minister of Public Works and the former Provincial Secretary.

Hamilton remains Attorney General.

An excursion party leaves Winnipeg for Victoria, Sept. 4th.

Sir Charles Dilke recently passed through here under a cloud of favour of Beach.

Gladstone's pamphlet on the Irish question has been issued, and has joined the loud Government schemes of a new Ministry.

The building magazine belonging to the Latin Powder Co., Chicago, was struck by lightning yesterday. The building was destroyed instantly, the fire quickly spread and twenty-five others more or less injured.

Three of the Bulgarian Ministers connected with the deposition of Alexander have been sentenced to imprisonment for life.

It is understood the Quebec elections will be held on the 27th Sept.

Sir Wilfrid Laurier.

Mr. Laurier, Mr. Blake and Messrs. Macdonalds large gathering of Liberals in Ottawa on Monday night.

Mr. Laurier, Mr. Blake and Mr. Macdonald were given a reception by the Conservative and adherents were invited to join them. Mr. Laurier said that he had returned to politics, and if he had to remain in politics another year he would do so again.

Egan was presented Monday with a watch by the Boarded Tradesmen's Association. Later Mr. Egan and Mr. Macdonald gave him a purse of ten dollars and a gold watch.

Egan left today for the west.

Van Horne going to St. Paul at the request of the Canadian Pacific.

Sir Charles Dilke, who has been travelling through Montana and the North-west under the name Macdonald, went under the name Falstaff, in order to avoid the Press crowd, which followed A. Smith.

McKinnon is not to become the Superintendent of the western division of the Canadian Pacific Railway. The position has been accepted by William Porter, president of the eastern division.

A shock of earthquake we felt yesterday throughout the United States. No damage was done to their houses, etc., but no damage done.

The Canadian Pacific has made a successful test of Canadian mail.

Tremors were felt in Idaho, Montana, Wallace Ross and Bank in the interior, and sailing ships in England to-day.

The weather will be fine today Beach and Turner. Great excitement.
